lines.text: Alarum. Enter YORK, EDWARD, RICHARD, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and Soldiers

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: While we pursued the horsemen of the north, He slily stole away and left his men: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland, Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat, Cheer'd up the drooping army; and himself, Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast, Charged our main battle's front, and breaking in Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.

lines.speaker: edward
lines.text: Lord Stafford's father, Duke of Buckingham, Is either slain or wounded dangerously; I cleft his beaver with a downright blow: That this is true, father, behold his blood.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood, Whom I encounter'd as the battles join'd.

lines.speaker: richard
lines.text: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.
Throwing down SOMERSET's head

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons. But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!

lines.speaker: richard
lines.text: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: And so do I. Victorious Prince of York, Before I see thee seated in that throne Which now the house of Lancaster usurps, I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close. This is the palace of the fearful king, And this the regal seat: possess it, York; For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will; For hither we have broken in by force.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Thanks, gentle Norfolk: stay by me, my lords; And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.
They go up

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: And when the king comes, offer no violence, Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: The queen this day here holds her parliament, But little thinks we shall be of her council: By words or blows here let us win our right.

lines.speaker: richard
lines.text: Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: The bloody parliament shall this be call'd, Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king, And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice Hath made us by-words to our enemies.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute; I mean to take possession of my right.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Neither the king, nor he that loves him best, The proudest he that holds up Lancaster, Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells. I'll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, CLIFFORD, NORTHUMBERLAND, WESTMORELAND, EXETER, and the rest

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits, Even in the chair of state: belike he means, Back'd by the power of Warwick, that false peer, To aspire unto the crown and reign as king. Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father. And thine, Lord Clifford; and you both have vow'd revenge On him, his sons, his favourites and his friends.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: If I be not, heavens be revenged on me!

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: What, shall we suffer this? let's pluck him down: My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: Patience is for poltroons, such as he: He durst not sit there, had your father lived. My gracious lord, here in the parliament Let us assail the family of York.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Ah, know you not the city favours them, And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: But when the duke is slain, they'll quickly fly.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart, To make a shambles of the parliament-house! Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats Shall be the war that Henry means to use. Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne, and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet; I am thy sovereign.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: I am thine.

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown In following this usurping Henry.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: It must and shall be so: content thyself.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster; And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget That we are those which chased you from the field And slew your fathers, and with colours spread March'd through the city to the palace gates.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief; And, by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons, Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words, I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger As shall revenge his death before I stir.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Will you we show our title to the crown? If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown? Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York; Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March: I am the son of Henry the Fifth, Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop And seized upon their towns and provinces.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: The lord protector lost it, and not I: When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.

lines.speaker: richard
lines.text: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose. Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.

lines.speaker: edward
lines.text: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms, Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

lines.speaker: richard
lines.text: Sound drums and trumpets, and the king will fly.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Sons, peace!

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Peace, thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords; And be you silent and attentive too, For he that interrupts him shall not live.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne, Wherein my grandsire and my father sat? No: first shall war unpeople this my realm; Ay, and their colours, often borne in France, And now in England to our heart's great sorrow, Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords? My title's good, and better far than his.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: 'Twas by rebellion against his king.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: [Aside]  I know not what to say; my title's weak.-- Tell me, may not a king adopt an heir?

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: What then?

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: An if he may, then am I lawful king; For Richard, in the view of many lords, Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth, Whose heir my father was, and I am his.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: He rose against him, being his sovereign, And made him to resign his crown perforce.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd, Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown?

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: No; for he could not so resign his crown But that the next heir should succeed and reign.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: [Aside]  All will revolt from me, and turn to him.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st, Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power, Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent, Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud, Can set the duke up in despite of me.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong, Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence: May that ground gape and swallow me alive, Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown. What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Do right unto this princely Duke of York, Or I will fill the house with armed men, And over the chair of state, where now he sits, Write up his title with usurping blood.
He stamps with his foot and the soldiers show themselves

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs, And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: I am content: Richard Plantagenet, Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: What wrong is this unto the prince your son!

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: What good is this to England and himself!

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: Base, fearful and despairing Henry!

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: How hast thou injured both thyself and us!

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: I cannot stay to hear these articles.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Nor I.

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: Come, cousin, let us tell the queen these news.

lines.speaker: westmoreland
lines.text: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king, In whose cold blood no spark of honour bides.

lines.speaker: northumberland
lines.text: Be thou a prey unto the house of York, And die in bands for this unmanly deed!

lines.speaker: clifford
lines.text: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome, Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!
Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, CLIFFORD, and WESTMORELAND

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Ah, Exeter!

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Why should you sigh, my lord?

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son, Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit. But be it as it may: I here entail The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever; Conditionally, that here thou take an oath To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live, To honour me as thy king and sovereign, And neither by treason nor hostility To seek to put me down and reign thyself.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: This oath I willingly take and will perform.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!
Sennet. Here they come down

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: And I'll keep London with my soldiers.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: And I unto the sea from whence I came.
Exeunt YORK, EDWARD, EDMUND, GEORGE, RICHARD,  WARWICK, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, their Soldiers, and Attendants

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.
Enter QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger: I'll steal away.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Exeter, so will I.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Who can be patient in such extremes? Ah, wretched man! would I had died a maid And never seen thee, never borne thee son, Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus? Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I, Or felt that pain which I did for him once, Or nourish'd him as I did with my blood, Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there, Rather than have that savage duke thine heir And disinherited thine only son.

lines.speaker: prince edward
lines.text: Father, you cannot disinherit me: If you be king, why should not I succeed?

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced? I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch! Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me; And given unto the house of York such head As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance. To entail him and his heirs unto the crown, What is it, but to make thy sepulchre And creep into it far before thy time? Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais; Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas; The duke is made protector of the realm; And yet shalt thou be safe? such safety finds The trembling lamb environed with wolves. Had I been there, which am a silly woman, The soldiers should have toss'd me on their pikes Before I would have granted to that act. But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed, Until that act of parliament be repeal'd Whereby my son is disinherited. The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours Will follow mine, if once they see them spread; And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace And utter ruin of the house of York. Thus do I leave thee. Come, son, let's away; Our army is ready; come, we'll after them.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.

lines.speaker: prince edward
lines.text: When I return with victory from the field I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.
Exeunt QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Poor queen! how love to me and to her son Hath made her break out into terms of rage! Revenged may she be on that hateful duke, Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire, Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle Tire on the flesh of me and of my son! The loss of those three lords torments my heart: I'll write unto them and entreat them fair. Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.
Exeunt
